pullRequest.body:
Mathematically Riemann zeta is not defined at 1, but our construction ascribes a value to `ζ 1`. This PR calculates the value, and shows that it is not zero.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:

- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

nodes.body: I'm wondering what this is good for (apart perhaps from `completedRiemannZeta₀_one`), as it seems that we are talking about "junk values" here that should be irrelevant in applications. @loefflerd, can you explain what purpose you have in mind with this?

> I'm wondering what this is good for (apart perhaps from `completedRiemannZeta₀_one`), as it seems that we are talking about "junk values" here that should be irrelevant in applications. @loefflerd, can you explain what purpose you have in mind with this?

`completedRiemannZeta₀ 1 = (γ - Complex.log (4 * ↑π)) / 2 + 1 =` [OEIS A074760](https://oeis.org/A074760).

When I initially added the statement of the Riemann hypothesis to mathlib, I formalised it as "if s is not a negative even integer and `ζ s = 0`, then `re s = 1/2`". Kevin pointed out that this statement might very well be false if the value for `ζ 1` was not well chosen, and took me to task on his public twitter feed for my sloppiness. 

So the main motivation of this PR is to clear up this mess by demonstrating that the value we assigned for `ζ 1` was nonzero all along.

More generally, there is a convention that "junk" values should be explicit; e.g. we have a lemma `div_zero` saying that `x / 0 = 0`, we don't just assign a random value but never disclose what it is. (For this reason I seem to recall one of the reviewers when I first added the zeta function – not sure who, maybe Sebastien? – writing that it would be good if we had a lemma explaining precisely what `ζ 1` is.)

OK. It certainly does not hurt to have this, and the value of `Λ₀` at 1 could be useful (and it needs the other ones anyway).
I won't "maintainer merge" (yet), so that Kevin has an opportunity to have a look.
maintainer merge

LGTM!

LGTM!
@kbuzzard are you going to have a look?

bors merge

```suggestion
    (Gammaℝ_one.trans_ne one_ne_zero)
```
That's a handy lemma, I didn't know about that one :smile:
There are many `trans_xx` lemmas that can often be useful.

```suggestion
  convert this using 2
```
speeds it up by a third :smile:

This looks like `norm_cast` should be able to do it (after `rw [riemannZeta_one]`).
I think the problem is `ofReal_log` that needs a positivity assumption (`ofReal_log` is also not tagged `norm_cast`, but trying to add the attribute locally does not help). It would be nice if `norm_cast` could do this, but this is another topic...

Do you prefer
```
  suffices (γ - (4 * π).log) / 2 ≠ 0 by
    simpa only [riemannZeta_one, ← ofReal_ne_zero, ofReal_log (by positivity : 0 ≤ 4 * π), 
      push_cast]
```
? It is a little slower, but not very much.
I think it is a bit clearer than doing all the explicit rewrites with `ofReal` lemmas, so yes.
Gesagt, getan.

```suggestion
  · exact Real.eulerMascheroniConstant_lt_two_thirds.trans (by norm_num)
```

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(NumberTheory/Harmonic): explicit formula for `ζ 1`
